Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A novel parallax-free, 360 degree panoramic camera system
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to advance long-form panoramic content capture at reduced cost. While content creators and producers seek panoramic content capture to create immersive viewing experiences, current approaches integrate many shots that consequently require expensive and time-intensive post-production. This project will save costs and labor by enabling seamless real-time capture of cinematic-quality panoramic content. Potential applications include security, risk and asset management, robotics, mapping, and live event capture; sectors that can benefit include navigation, aviation, tourism, construction, manufacturing, and entertainment.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop an innovative camera system that fuses images captured through a camera array at the level of the lenses, rendering a perfect 360Â° image instantaneously. Minimizing overlapping image capture reduces the problems of parallax error and perspective errors, while valuable camera resolution is not lost on redundancy. This project will: 1) develop software; and 2) validate opto-mechanical alignment and assembly concepts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Circle Optics is developing the world?s first parallax-free, 360? panoramic camera system by using an innovative design that employs a polyhedron-shaped configuration of adjacent cameras, with each camera closely abutting the next, allowing for seamless capture of 360? views while limiting blind regions and lost content between cameras. This report reviews the progress of Circle Optics during an NSF Phase I Award period that started September 1st, 2020, and has carried forward into 2021, during which progress was made towards completing a 2nd generation system, Hydra Beta. As anticipated in the Phase I proposal, during the award period, Circle Optics has progressed the optical and opto-mechanical designs, while conducting design reviews and validating component manufacturing concerns with select vendors. While the lens design was substantially complete pre-award, lens element drawings were shared with vendors, and adjustments were made to benefit the opto-mechanical yield and performance. The design of the lens housings and the support hardware were likewise changed after a combination of drawing reviews with vendors and testing with preliminary mechanical models to examine tolerances, kinematics, and space constraint issues. Optical and opto-mechanical assembly concepts have also been developed, and the design of the associated assembly tools and fixtures is being completed. In parallel, geometric calibration software has been developed and tested, and specifications for the sensor data path boards have been refined with the vendor and sensor boards are on order. During the award period, Circle Optics also participated in the NSF I-Corps program, during which we completed a pivot from commercial entertainment markets towards defense markets.

Circle Optics has been broadly aware of the potential of our technology to enable capture of real-time, panoramic image content for a wide range of applications, including those in entertainment (cinema, VR, or sporting events), education (e.g., pilot or driver training), mapping, security and surveillance, and robotics. However, Circle Optics participation in the NSF I-Corps program expanded and reinforced the potential for our technology to enhance functionality for a broad range of applications where real-time situational awareness of structures or events in an environment is a priority, particularly for defense applications such as sensing and tracking missiles. But it is now also understood that the applications for real-time situational awareness is much broader and can include equipping drones to fixed systems to monitor a battlefield, the environment including forests or wilderness, farmland, or equipping vehicles, aircraft, or satellites to monitor traffic, moving debris, or threats such as missiles, or equipping airports or city streets to monitor for traffic or accident risks. Circle Optics is also becoming more aware of the different specifications or requirements that the hardware needs to support this diverse range of potential applications.

As Circle Optics develops camera and system designs for these markets, insights are gained about how to design, manufacture, and enable practical use of the technology. These insights are being published to varying extents in patent applications and on the company website, but eventually they will also be shared in appropriate technical or trade publications. But beyond Circle Optics internal activities, the technology, once commercialized, can enable progress in a host of other research fields or endeavors in which the capture of real-time high-resolution panoramic image content to provide broad knowledge of activities and changes within an environment is useful. As examples, Circle Optics systems may eventually be used to study the behavior of wildlife, or to document the impact of climate change, or to analyze crowd dynamics.
